metadata.how_to_trigger: With Gale as Companion, approach the shrine of Mystra (S_LOW_MystraStatue_ab6b7142-2333-4b38-9506-fb3e72157145) and click on it.

21.speaker: Narrator
21.text: *There she stands, just as Elminster promised. Mystra. Goddess of the Weave. Mother of all magic.*
21.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player gazes up at the statue of Mystra. She appears beautiful, imposing, indifferent.

54.speaker: Gale
54.text: The old man wasn't lying. She's opened a summoning channel. Can't you feel it?
54.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale looks at the statue of MystraNodeContext: Can't quite believe it

61.speaker: Narrator
61.text: *Gale's right. The very air around the statue crackles with magic, as though the Weave itself were coursing beneath her stony skin.*

117.speaker: Gale
117.text: A stream of pure, undiluted Weave. I only have to reach out, and it will carry me to Mystra, wherever she may be.

99.speaker: Narrator
99.text: *Gale's right. The very air around the statue crackles with magic. It sets your teeth on edge.*

64.speaker: Narrator
64.text: *There she stands. Mystra. Goddess of the Weave. Mother of all magic.*
64.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player gazes up at the statue of Mystra. She appears beautiful, imposing, indifferent.

75.speaker: Gale
75.text: Strange... Do you feel that? It's as though the Weave itself is rushing past us...

29.speaker: Gale
29.text: It's a summoning channel, the kind Mystra once used to call me to her side. I only have to reach for it, and it will take me to her side.

3.speaker: Jaheira
3.text: Well? Are you composing a poem in your head, or some such?
3.context: NodeContext: Impatient, but in an amused way. Gale is suddenly shy about answering his goddess / lover's call.

63.speaker: Gale
63.text: Time was I'd have given my right arm for a chance to speak with Mystra again. The left one too. Maybe a knee...

83.speaker: Gale
83.context: CinematicNodeContext: The player nods firmly in response

43.speaker: Gale
43.text: You're right. I am a strong, capable wizard. And this is no more than a casual reunion with an ex-lover.

70.speaker: Gale
70.context: NodeContext: It's getting on top of hi again, he's getting nervous again

51.speaker: Player
51.text: You don't owe her so much as a fingernail. She asked you to blow yourself up.

95.speaker: Gale
95.text: Not the message one hopes to receive from a past lover. But her first love was always the Weave. At best, I was a close second.

97.speaker: Player
97.text: I don't think she's that kind of goddess.

12.speaker: Gale
12.text: Thankfully not. Though she's not been averse to demanding the odd human sacrifice in recent days, has she?
12.context: NodeContext: black humour, referring to the fact she asked him to blow himself up

68.speaker: Gale
68.text: When I pictured this moment, I thought I'd feel more in control. Yet here I am, with palms sweatier than a bugbear's armpit.

46.speaker: Gale
46.text: I always wondered what being nervous would feel like. I hate it.

108.speaker: Player
108.text: Do you know what you're going to say to her?

115.speaker: Player
115.text: Of all the things to be nervous about, an audience with a goddess seems reasonable.

102.speaker: Gale
102.text: You're kind to say so, but this is hardly my first time in Mystra's presence. It's more the matter of what I'm going to say to her.

76.speaker: Player
76.text: Why do you care what she thinks of you?

1.speaker: Gale
1.text: You know what it is to worship her, to respect her, to love her...

48.speaker: Gale
48.text: It was intoxicating. An experience beyond expression.

80.speaker: Gale
80.text: During my time locked away in Waterdeep, I prepared a quite comprehensive speech for her on the subject of our former relationship, and the manner in which it ended.

15.speaker: Gale
15.text: Alas, recent events have rendered the majority of it moot, so I'm going to have to improvise. Unless you have any words of wisdom to impart before I go?

11.speaker: Player
11.text: You're not taking me with you?

13.speaker: Gale
13.text: The summoning channel Mystra has provided is for me alone. No one else is permitted to enter it, no matter how talented a user of the Weave they are.

27.speaker: Gale
27.text: The summoning channel Mystra has provided is one only I can enter. No matter how much I'd prefer not to face her alone.

72.speaker: Player
72.text: Seek her forgiveness, Gale. It might be your only hope of curing the orb.

105.speaker: Gale
105.text: Mystra's forgiveness? If you want me to claim the Crown of Karsus, she'll hardly be in a forgiving mood after that.

107.speaker: Gale
107.text: I think it's best I keep a cool head going into this. Approach it like a particularly high-risk round of Three-Dragon Ante.

5.speaker: Gale
5.text: I'll let Mystra show her flight, and then I can see how strong a chance we stand of winning the gambit.
5.context: NodeContext: 'Ante' and 'flight' are terms used in a d&d equivalent of poker. 'flight' = cards and 'gambitt' = round.

40.speaker: Gale
40.text: I'll only be gone for a matter of moments. The Outer Planes experience time quite differently to our own.

52.speaker: Gale
52.text: You're right. A heartfelt apology is the surest way to a goddess' heart, and her favour.

18.speaker: Gale
18.text: I'd pray that she'll be in a forgiving mood, if she weren't the one I'd be praying to.

35.speaker: Player
35.text: Make her squirm. Tell her the Crown will be ours soon enough.

23.speaker: Gale
23.text: With pleasure. It's not often one has the chance to threaten a goddess and make good on it.

90.speaker: Gale
90.text: Mystra won't be the one issuing the orders for much longer. She'll know exactly who's coming for her.

59.speaker: Gale
59.text: This won't take long, and when I'm done, I'll be free of Mystra's yoke once and for all.

16.context: CinematicNodeContext: Gale reaches a hand out in front of him, closes his eyes. A brilliant flash of white light and - he's in the Outer planes. Before him, Mystra in her celestial form.

45.speaker: Mystra
45.text: Gale of Waterdeep. You look well.
45.context: NodeContext: Not giving much away - both a pleasantry on an awkward reunion with her ex, and carrying the added implication of the fact Mystra told Gale to blow himself up, yet he stands before her, alive and well

41.speaker: Gale
41.text: Mystra. I never thought we'd speak again like this. Why am I here?

73.speaker: Mystra
73.text: There is much unsaid between us, but time runs ever short.
73.context: NodeContext: "much unsaid' carries a lot of weight - could refer to their relationship, their breakup, Gale's betrayal etc. Mystra is subtly keeping control of the conversation.

26.speaker: Mystra
26.text: You discovered what lies at the Heart of the Absolute - the Crown of Karsus - and you disobeyed my instruction. Why?
26.context: NodeContext: Big question - this was the quest Mystra gave to the player in Act 2, which they refused to complete. Mystra containing her frustration, but needs to know the answer. 'Heart of the Absolute' was the term used for what turned out to be the brain/Crown

112.speaker: Gale
112.text: I didn't want to die. And when I saw the Crown, I thought I might not have to, if I only understood its power.

0.speaker: Mystra
0.text: And you believe you have the right to such an understanding?
0.context: NodeContext: Hint of an eyebrow raise - is this a sign of Gale's same old hubris?

49.speaker: Mystra
49.text: The past cannot be undone with self-pity, nor can a future be forged. Only with the truth will you see the way ahead.
49.context: NodeContext: Not letting him off easily

30.speaker: Mystra
30.text: The fragment of magic you tried to return to me was not of my creation. It was the Karsite Weave.
30.context: NodeContext: 'Fragment of magic' referring to the orb in Gale's chest. 'Karsite Weave' with distaste - the creation of someone she hates

4.speaker: Mystra
4.text: It is a corrupted, half-born magic wrought in the brief moment Karsus ascended to godhood. It hungers for power just as he did, and it can never be sated.
4.context: NodeContext: Weighty/strong sentiment here - the Karsite Weave is an abomination in her eyes

22.speaker: Mystra
22.text: You unleashed something that would consume all magic in existence, and yet you thought only of preserving yourself.
22.context: NodeContext: 'Am I wrong?'. Referring back to Gale unleashing the orb, and then coming to Mystra to ask her to cure him of it.

88.speaker: Gale
88.text: That can't be. It wasn't - it couldn't have been. I only wished to prove myself worthy. I had no idea...

25.speaker: Mystra
25.text: You were already worthy. What you lacked was patience, and it cost you dearly.
25.context: NodeContext: Hint of gentleness - recognising some of Gale's pain

24.speaker: Mystra
24.text: When the Karsite Weave entered your body, your gifts were the first thing it consumed.
24.context: NodeContext: Hint of gentleness - recognising some of Gale's pain

55.speaker: Mystra
55.text: The only reason the 'orb' sleeps is because I have allowed it to feed on the true Weave - a temporary measure, but one that will not be enough to save us.
55.context: NodeContext: "This is what your foolishness has cost". New information for the player, who believes Mystra simply waved her hand and fixed them because it suited her.

66.speaker: Mystra
66.text: With each day that passes, the elder brain threatens to become a new kind of god, its worshippers a scourge of soulless illithids.
66.context: NodeContext: Hinting at the fact the elder brain will soon evolve, becoming free of the dead three's control. A terrible vision for the future.

47.speaker: Mystra
47.text: If you will not use the orb to end this abomination, then you must find a way to separate Crown and host. When you've done this, you must surrender the Crown of Karsus to me.

57.speaker: Gale
57.text: I won't let you down again. When the Absolute is vanquished, I will surrender Karsus' powers to you. You have my word.

86.speaker: Mystra
86.text: Thank you. May the Weave's light guide your purpose, and its wisdom guide your hand.
86.context: NodeContext: A blessing - Mystra relieved you'll do it

9.speaker: Mystra
9.text: The future of magic rests on your shoulders, Gale of Waterdeep.
9.context: NodeContext: Almost like a 'knighting' vibe - she's declaring her faith in him, and believes he can do this.

10.speaker: Mystra
10.text: I promise you - it is a burden you are strong enough to bear.
10.context: NodeContext: Almost like a 'knighting' vibe - she's declaring her faith in him, and believes he can do this.

69.context: CinematicNodeContext: Mystra's form disappears. Gale stands in an ordinary temple before an ordinary statue once more. Mystra's idol gazes on, revealing nothing. Gale smiles to himself.

114.speaker: Gale
114.text: Not happening. When I get my hands on that Crown, I'm going to wield it. Karsus' powers will be mine.

113.speaker: Mystra
113.text: Crown yourself, Gale Dekarios, and you will learn what it is to carry such weight upon your shoulders.
113.context: NodeContext: An icy edge entering her voice - a hint at the challenge Gale will face if he pursues this course

78.speaker: Mystra
78.text: If it does not crush you, I will.
78.context: NodeContext: Here we glimpse the true, unimaginable power of Mystra. She's still in control of herself, but her anger should be palpable.

36.speaker: Gale
36.text: A great ask indeed. You've given me much to think on - as you always did.

65.speaker: Mystra
65.text: So be it. Follow the needle of your own wisdom. We shall see how truly it leads you.
65.context: NodeContext: Neutral - not impressed he hasn't outright agreed to what she asked, but willing to give him the time he needs.

62.speaker: Gale
62.text: Well somebody had to. You weren't exactly forthcoming with any offers of help.

44.speaker: Mystra
44.text: My concern was the preservation of everything. The Karsite Weave could tear apart the very fabric of the Material Plane.
44.context: NodeContext: A hint of anger here - Gale's selfishness is not her own, he's pissing her off by accusing her of these motives

100.speaker: Mystra
100.text: That it entered your body and consumed no more than your powers was a miracle. But we will not be granted another.
100.context: NodeContext: A hint of anger here - Gale's selfishness is not her own, he's pissing her off by accusing her of these motives. The 'miracle' is that Gale didn't do any more damage, not that he survived. Sense of foreboding on the last sentence.

7.speaker: Gale
7.text: So that's what you're scared of. With the Crown of Karsus reforged, I could take control of the Karsite Weave.

60.speaker: Mystra
60.text: You can no more control the Karsite Weave than a weather vane could control a storm.
60.context: NodeContext: A personal warning for Gale, but not specifically that 'he' couldn't control it - no mortal could. Stern, warning

8.speaker: Gale
8.text: You abandoned me in my hour of greatest need. I had no obligation to help you in yours.

71.speaker: Mystra
71.text: You still believe yourself to be so wronged? You always were stubborn.
71.context: NodeContext: Hint of an eyebrow raise - is this a sign of Gale's same old hubris?

17.speaker: Gale
17.text: Because you had no right to ask that of me. You cast me out, remember?

19.speaker: Mystra
19.text: You were my lover, my Chosen, yet still you know so little of me.
19.context: NodeContext: Hint of disappointment - even after all the advantages I gave you, you can't see further than your own nose

50.speaker: Gale
50.text: No thanks to you. I wasn't expecting a summons, but then you did always prefer things on your terms.

87.speaker: Mystra
87.text: I did not come here to suffer a mortal's admonitions. Certainly not yours.
87.context: NodeContext: restrained, but taking no nonsense

103.speaker: Gale
103.text: As do you. But I assume we're not here solely to exchange compliments. So, why am I here?

20.speaker: Gale
20.text: It's one thing for us to actually pursue the Crown. I'm not entirely sure I want to threaten Mystra with the prospect on her own turf, so to speak.

58.speaker: Player
58.text: Don't give anything away. Just find out what she has to say.

93.speaker: Gale
93.text: You'd make a fine Three-Dragon Ante player, you know.

77.speaker: Player
77.text: You shouldn't go to her, Gale. Don't give her the satisfaction.

111.speaker: Gale
111.text: What do you mean? I've been waiting for an opportunity like this since long before our paths crossed.

104.speaker: Gale
104.text: This is my only opportunity to learn the truth. About the Crown, the orb, all of it. Why try to keep me from it?

109.speaker: Player
109.text: You're right. If you want to go, you should go.

91.speaker: Player
91.text: Even with the orb, you're one of the best wizards in the Realms. You don't need Mystra's help.

84.speaker: Gale
84.text: Fine. If you're so against the idea, I suppose we can forge ahead without input from the goddess of magic.

79.speaker: Gale
79.text: I'm sure she has nothing pertinent to share whatsoever.

96.speaker: Gale
96.text: Confident almost to the point of arrogance I may be, but in this matter I know she'll have wisdom to share. As for whether I choose to act upon it... we shall see.

74.speaker: Gale
74.text: I don't suppose you can imagine what it's like, to have your god as your lover...

106.speaker: Gale
106.text: For a wizard, to have the love of the goddess of magic herself...

85.speaker: Player
85.text: Pull it together. You're going to make a fool of yourself otherwise.

56.speaker: Gale
56.text: Oh that hardly matters. There's not much further I could fall in Mystra's estimation. But I'd like to at least leave her with something to think about.

42.speaker: Player
42.text: I'd give more than a few limbs to be summoned to Mystra's presence, to look on the Mother of Magic herself...

37.speaker: Gale
37.text: You have more faith in her than even I did... Understandable, though, when you have not loved her as deeply, or known the depths of her affections.

6.speaker: Nightwarden Minthara
6.text: Your goddess awaits. Hear her out, but remember that you do not owe her obedience, and you certainly do not owe her your life.

38.speaker: Lae'zel
38.text: Your goddess calls. Serve her or denounce her as you will - but you cannot ignore her.

39.speaker: Wyll
39.text: Go on, my good man. You can't exactly deny a goddess, now can you?

82.speaker: Shadowheart
82.text: Mystra is a lesser goddess compared to Lady Shar, but if you have a chance to speak to her, you should seize it.
82.context: NodeContext: 'An audience with your goddess ' = SH has turned from Shar. 'Mystra is a lesser goddess' = SH is loyal to Shar.

94.speaker: Astarion
94.text: Well? Go on, then - it's rude to keep a goddess waiting.

110.speaker: Minsc
110.text: Eh... the first step is difficult, of course. Minsc could throw you in, if you prefer?
110.context: NodeContext: Genuinely being helpful. Gale stands wondering whether to answer Mystra's summoning portal.

118.speaker: Halsin
118.text: Do what you must, Gale. Mystra has weighed upon your heart and mind for too long.

33.speaker: Karlach
33.text: Go on then, Gale. We'll be here waiting for you when you're finished.
33.context: NodeContext: Encouraging, like telling a friend to go chat to their ex while you wait in the car ready to debrief after.
